title: 103_hr929
content: The text chunk discusses the simplification of employment taxes on domestic services by increasing the threshold requirement from $50 to $300. It also addresses the coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with the collection of income taxes. The text chunk outlines the general rules for filing returns on domestic service employment taxes on a calendar year basis. It also discusses the treatment of these taxes for estimated tax provisions under section 6654. For the taxable year beginning in 1994, adjustments will be made to the application of section 6654(d)(2) regarding the amount treated as tax. Domestic service employment taxes include taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home and amounts withheld under section 3402(p). The term does not include service described in section 3121(g)(5). There is an exception where the employer is liable for other employment taxes as determined by the Secretary's regulations. The Secretary may prescribe regulations to exempt employers liable for other employment taxes from section 3121(g)(5). The Secretary can also enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. Any taxes collected will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The amount collected under the agreement will be treated as a tax imposed by chapter 23 for purposes of subtitle F. The term 'State' is defined as given in section 3306(j)(1). The amendments in Sec. 3510 coordinate the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes, effective for remuneration paid after 1993.
